title: What happens if you guess? - Leigh Nataro

multiple-choice.question: What is the fundamental counting principle?

options.label: A
options.text: The principle states that if there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A times B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: B
options.text: The principle states that if there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A minus B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: The principle states that if there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A plus B ways to pair the outcomes.

options.label: D
options.text: The principle states that if there are A possible outcomes for one event, and B possible outcomes for another event, then there are A to the power of B ways to pair the outcomes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of the probability of getting a perfect score by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
What is the average score you would get right by guessing on a 10-question true/false quiz?
If there are 20 questions and five possible answers for each question, what is the probability you would get all 20 right by randomly guessing?

options.label: D
options.text: 1 in 95 trillion

multiple-choice.question: What should you expect your score to be if you and all your friends were to always randomly guess at every question on a 20-question true/false quiz?
What is the term for the process of asking questions that yield a compelling narrative in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Sourcing

options.label: B
options.text: Storytelling

options.label: C
options.text: Narrative solicitation

options.label: D
options.text: Journalism trifecta

multiple-choice.question: What are the three components of the trifecta of sourcing in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and primary sources

options.label: B
options.text: Official sources, unofficial sources, and data sources

options.label: C
options.text: Official sources, overview sources, and unofficial sources

options.label: D
options.text: Primary sources, secondary sources, and tertiary sources

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of unofficial sources in the trifecta of sourcing?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide facts and data

options.label: B
options.text: To offer a big-picture view

options.label: C
options.text: To provide individual insight and personal anecdotes

options.label: D
options.text: To verify information

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of asking surprising questions in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: To present information quickly

options.label: B
options.text: To convey a message clearly

options.label: C
options.text: To mine for compelling stories and anecdotes

options.label: D
options.text: To verify facts and data

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the personal stories that contribute to the narrative in journalism?

options.label: A
options.text: Anecdotes

options.label: B
options.text: Exposition

options.label: C
options.text: Facts and data

options.label: D
options.text: Bulleted information

title: How fiction can change reality - Jessica Wise

multiple-choice.question: What does it mean to be a Native American?

options.label: A
options.text: That you were among the largest group of people living in the United States of America.

options.label: B
options.text: That you are among the most important groups of people living in the United States of America.

options.label: C
options.text: That you were one of the original people who lived in the United States of America.

options.label: D
options.text: That you were one of the founding fathers of the United States of America.

multiple-choice.question: There are more than 500 Native American tribes and nations. Which 5 tribes were the largest?

options.label: A
options.text: Apache, Cherokee, Iroquois, Navajo, and Sioux

options.label: B
options.text: Cherokee, Anasazi, Chippewa, Pawnee, and Osage

options.label: C
options.text: Apache, Iroquois, Chippewa, Pawnee, and Lakota

options.label: D
options.text: Navajo, Sioux, Lakota, Pawnee, and Osage

multiple-choice.question: What does the tribe name Cherokee mean?

options.label: A
options.text: People known as farmers.

options.label: B
options.text: People known as warriors.

options.label: C
options.text: People with another language.

options.label: D
options.text: People with another religion.

multiple-choice.question: What is a "wigwam"?

options.label: A
options.text: A farming technique that increases crops.

options.label: B
options.text: A shelter built from branches, leaves, and grass.

options.label: C
options.text: A shelter built from mud bricks and clay.

options.label: D
options.text: A fishing technique that used a spear.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Navajo tribe?

options.label: A
options.text: They were known for their skills in agriculture.

options.label: B
options.text: They were known for their skills in hunting.

options.label: C
options.text: They were known for their skills in fishing.

options.label: D
options.text: They were known for their skills in warfare.

multiple-choice.question: Their eyeballs are a major component of their skulls. On the video, they gave a comparison if humans had pigeon-like eyeballs. How big would the human eyeballs be?

options.label: A
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of tomatoes.

options.label: B
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of watermelons.

options.label: C
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of grapefruits.

options.label: D
options.text: Human eyeballs would be the size of baseballs.

multiple-choice.question: Why was Charles Darwin, the father of evolution theory, so interested in pigeons to support his theory?

options.label: A
options.text: Darwin knew that every country had a form of pigeons.

options.label: B
options.text: Darwin knew that despite the differences, pigeons all came from the Rock Dove.

options.label: C
options.text: Darwin was able to examine pigeons more easily than other animals.

options.label: D
options.text: Darwin thought the fancy pigeons would attract more attention than armadillos.

multiple-choice.question: What is the size of a pigeon's brain?

options.label: A
options.text: The size of your thumb

options.label: B
options.text: The size of a fingertip

options.label: C
options.text: The size of a walnut

options.label: D
options.text: The size of a golf ball

multiple-choice.question: What do pigeons' "super eyes" allow them to do?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to be more balanced and agile than humans.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows them to magnify their focus on objects.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows them to remember things humans can't.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows them to see things humans can't.

multiple-choice.question: Why did B.F. Skinner try and train pigeons during World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: He trained them to help crash enemy planes.

options.label: B
options.text: He trained them to deliver messages.

options.label: C
options.text: He trained them in order to make them aerial bombers.

options.label: D
options.text: He trained them to crack enemy messages.

multiple-choice.question: One study found that ____ percent of news coverage about Islam and Muslims is negative.
What is one thing going to mosques more frequently linked to?

options.label: A
options.text: More tolerant views of people of other faiths

options.label: B
options.text: Greater civic engagement

options.label: C
options.text: Both A and B

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Christianity

options.label: C
options.text: White supremacy

options.label: A
options.text: Vocal

options.label: B
options.text: Silent

options.label: C
options.text: Negative

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What did Emily Dickinson say about books?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a waste of time.

options.label: B
options.text: They can take us lands away.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only for the rich.

options.label: D
options.text: They are only for the poor.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that novels have helped shape the minds of thought leaders across history?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing them with scientific evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: By challenging traditional ideologies.

options.label: C
options.text: By providing them with practical skills.

options.label: D
options.text: By providing them with historical facts.

multiple-choice.question: What is one characteristic that is shared by heroes in novels, such as "Harry Potter" and "Great Expectations"?

options.label: A
options.text: They are all weak and helpless.

options.label: B
options.text: They are all strong and brave.

options.label: C
options.text: They are all intelligent and adaptable.

options.label: D
options.text: They are all selfish and greedy.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that readers can engage with classic literature, such as "Pride and Prejudice" and "Jane Eyre"?

options.label: A
options.text: By ignoring the outdated social norms.

options.label: B
options.text: By reading them with a critical eye.

options.label: C
options.text: By reading them with an open mind.

options.label: D
options.text: By reading them with a negative attitude.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that new stories can influence and create change?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing scientific evidence.

options.label: B
options.text: By challenging traditional ideologies.

options.label: C
options.text: By providing practical skills.

options.label: D
options.text: By providing historical facts.

multiple-choice.question: What are logarithms, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A way of dealing with very small or extremely large numbers.

options.label: B
options.text: A concept used in chemistry to find the pH of water samples.

options.label: C
options.text: A method of solving equations with exponents.

options.label: D
options.text: A tool used in computer science to understand base 2.

multiple-choice.question: What is the formula to calculate pH, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: pH equals log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration.

options.label: B
options.text: pH equals negative log base 10 of the hydrogen ion concentration.

options.label: C
options.text: pH equals log base 2 of the hydrogen ion concentration.

options.label: D
options.text: pH equals negative log base 2 of the hydrogen ion concentration.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the difference between point 0000000398 and point 00000000398 in terms of pH, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The difference causes one to have red eyes after swimming.

options.label: B
options.text: The difference causes one to have itchy eyes after swimming.

options.label: C
options.text: The difference has no effect on eyes.

options.label: D
options.text: The difference is used to calculate the pH of water samples.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of using logarithms in chemistry, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To find the pH of water samples.

options.label: B
options.text: To calculate the concentration of hydrogen ions.

options.label: C
options.text: To understand the properties of acids and bases.

options.label: D
options.text: To solve equations with exponents.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of using logarithms in solving problems, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes problems more difficult to solve.

options.label: B
options.text: It makes problems easier to solve.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on solving problems.

options.label: D
options.text: It only applies to very small or extremely large numbers.

title: The history of keeping time - Karen Mensing

multiple-choice.question: What is the earliest known form of telling time?

options.label: A
options.text: The mechanical clock

options.label: B
options.text: The sundial

options.label: C
options.text: The hourglass

options.label: D
options.text: The atomic clock

multiple-choice.question: What is a limitation of sundials?

options.label: A
options.text: They require electricity to function

options.label: B
options.text: They are only accurate during the day

options.label: C
options.text: They are too expensive to build

options.label: D
options.text: They are too small to be useful

multiple-choice.question: What is the basis for scientific time today?

options.label: A
options.text: The swing of a pendulum

options.label: B
options.text: The vibration of a quartz crystal

options.label: C
options.text: A continuous count of seconds based on atomic clocks

options.label: D
options.text: The motion of the sun

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to keep track of time?

options.label: A
options.text: So we can sleep in late

options.label: B
options.text: So we can avoid doing chores

options.label: C
options.text: So we can accurately communicate with people all over the world

options.label: D
options.text: So we can forget about schedules

multiple-choice.question: What is a time zone?

options.label: A
options.text: A region on earth that has a uniform temperature

options.label: B
options.text: A region on earth that has a uniform standard time

options.label: C
options.text: A region on earth that has a uniform currency

options.label: D
options.text: A region on earth that has a uniform language
